Apr 11

Loyal consumers pay too a heavy price

That’s unfair — and it’s bad for the economy too.

You’d think loyalty would be rewarded. And in some markets it is.

But when it comes to essential services like energy and broadband, consumer loyalty is too often punished with unjustifiable price rises.

This all comes down to companies exploiting inertia. They know consumers lead busy lives and won’t get round to switching to a cheaper deal until it’s too late. And so companies, from energy suppliers to mobile phone providers, pursue a profitable pricing strategy: tempt new customers in with a competitive deal and then quietly raise the price over time.

Our new report shows how big the loyalty penalty can be. We looked at broadband deals and found that consumers are paying £113 more a year for their broadband once their initial contract ends. In some cases, the loyalty penalty was as high as £198 a year. On average, this means loyal broadband customers end up paying 43% more than the deal they started out on.

That’s a staggering figure and even bigger than the 12% price gap we see for loyal customers in the energy market.

Broadband prices jump up when your initial contract ends

So broadband customers pay a big price for inertia — and they’re not alone. A similar trick is being pulled across essential services, from energy bills that default onto the (much higher) standard variable tariff to mobile phone contracts that keep charging you the same monthly bill even after you’ve paid off the price of the handset.

Why does this matter? Don’t consumers have only themselves to blame if they don’t switch to a cheaper deal when they could?

In part, it’s about fairness. When loyalty is punished, vulnerable consumers end up paying the most. Nearly 80% of Britain’s elderly, disabled and low income households say they haven’t switched their energy bill for three years. Our new research finds that pensioners are more than twice as likely younger customers to have been on the same broadband contract for over 10 years.

So accepting the loyalty penalty means accepting that more vulnerable households will pay the most for their essential services.

But these outcomes aren’t just unfair, they’re economically harmful too. That’s because well-functioning consumer markets run on choice. Consumers proactively choose the products and services they buy, and fierce competition by companies for those choices is what drives prices down and fuels innovation and efficiency.

Inertia is the ultimate non-choice. No-one chooses to be on a standard energy tariff or an unnecessarily expensive third year broadband deal.

Worse, even if you wanted to choose your energy or broadband provider on that basis, it’s hard to do. The cost of out-of-contract tariffs is rarely advertised and is often buried deep on company websites, so it’s hard to choose the company that will rip you off least when your first contract ends. Over a third of consumers told us they weren’t even aware there was a loyalty penalty.

That’s one reason that non-choices have become a key feature of markets for essential services. And that leaves many of these markets looking superficially competitive but with all the symptoms of a competition failure.

Take energy as an example. There are now over 50 energy suppliers to choose from and, if you visit a price comparison website, there are plenty of good deals to be had. On the face of it, therefore, the market is competitive.

Meanwhile, at least two thirds of energy customers are on the ‘non-choice’ deal of the standard variable tariff, having failed to switch for too long. And that’s why the price most people pay for their energy bears little relationship to the wholesale price of energy, a clear symptom of failed competition.

It’s hard to overstate the importance of this: markets that look competitive are not delivering the benefits that competition should deliver. Worse, there’s reason to think this problem will grow. If you add together the power of big data, plus increasingly well-targeted advertising (and the use of cookies to personalise website content), plus insights into human behaviour, something important starts to change. It becomes easier and easier for companies — particularly big incumbent firms with a large customer base — to target one price at some customers while keeping others on uncompetitive deals.

And this all brings us to the challenge for policymakers: how do you solve a problem like the loyalty penalty, and all its attendant implications for competition, without killing off competition in the parts of the market that are working well? After all, the flip-side of loyal customers paying more for their energy or broadband is that customers who switch save money. And who would bother switching if there weren’t savings to be made? And what would that mean for competition in the wider market?

This is a difficult set of questions. And there’s no denying that there are trade-offs to be made. But the idea that nothing can be done to solve the loyalty penalty is a comfortable myth.

Here, as an example, are some things policymakers can do:

  • Use targeted price caps to protect vulnerable groups or to limit the size of the loyalty penalty without eliminating it entirely. In the energy market, for example, the government should extend a price cap to people eligible for the Warm Home Discount and they should weigh up the merits of a price cap on all SVTs to limit the extent of the loyalty penalty.
  • Require contracts to be structured in ways that reduce the loyalty penalty. For example, mobile phone companies should be required to split out the cost of the handset from the cost of the service contract itself, so that customers’ bills drop once they’ve paid off the handset.
  • Ban the most egregious tricks, such as the dangerous combination of free trials plus a tool called a Continuous Payment Authority. These are used to tempt in customers with a free deal before taking money directly from their bank account when the trial ends. The government has rightly said it will crackdown on the use of subscription traps like these.

So public policy can make markets fairer and more competitive — and it needs to. In markets from energy to broadband, the loyalty penalty isn’t just ripping off consumers, it’s also undermining the benefits of competition. Without action, that problem may only get worse.
